document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Career and Technical Education

70BA40241F2D461AA1F95B646279518F.description: determine time and cause of death methodologies through case studies.

2E170262F0D6444AA071065D751A880F.description: determine time of death using entomology;

5B140463EA14484EBC4F4C687D734E40.description: explain post mortem lividity and its importance when processing a crime scene;

CDB6C2D0B6C74C6FA1E897E83030E76D.description: explain the process and timeline of rigor mortis and its role in calculating time of death;

962793CC55F344CC8BDEF64E06ED65C1.description:
The student calculates the time and cause of death in relationship to decomposition of the human
body. The student is expected to:

9EFB485BC93B4DB88E2B84BE5ECC05EB.description: explain the role of dental records in identification of human remains.

22DC693151224890A23C4D025F160987.description:
explain the characteristics of the human skeletal system indicative of specific gender,
racial origin, and approximate range of age and height;

812A0C87FD784F83AF88446A393F1392.description: describe the techniques used to excavate bones from a crime scene;

3A2CAA178DD6456D995ABB5F334B2508.description: compare composition and structure of human bones with other animals;

4E57553F1E594B15BA4B093076F397C5.description: identify the major bones of the human skeletal system;

F27392AA8885436684670D9D8E619085.description:
The student explores principles of anthropology relevant to forensic science. The student is
expected to:

370ED23CCBBF44EABA6E63CBC2F60508.description: describe the process of ink analysis using chromatography

58CA7D19B1FA4B949A3AFB5F8A42879E.description:
perform handwriting comparisons of an unknown sample with exemplars by analyzing
characteristics such as letter, line, and formatting;

66C78DEEBFDB4BBDBE2535AEED67C71A.description: describe the security features incorporated in the U.S. currency to prevent counterfeiting;

983EC912CB3047B9A1DDCA65AB4740B0.description:
describe different types of examinations performed by a questioned document examiner
in a forensic laboratory, including counterfeiting, handwriting, ink, and paper analysis;

A27030C505ED4515931978AF317DB593.description:
The student explores principles of questioned document analysis in forensic science. The student
is expected to:

0BFA5373E4AA4764B7EBF47A6E8D0C67.description:
recognize the type of information available through the National Integrated Ballistics
Information Network.

9A51ECC712184CDBB79BAE6FCD2AF6F4.description:
describe the composition of and method of analysis for gunshot residue and primer
residue;

A43A249A93484457A988C1A08EDFD011.description: recognize characteristics of bullet and cartridge cases;

941518B26EF74DA5B7D6FE6314B697FB.description: describe the mechanism of modern firearms;

D43C718BFC3C4B789EAE6026DCA69BC8.description: explain the individual characteristics of tool marks;

4230330A73684E14B99D1BFB3C6689B7.description:
The student evaluates bullet and tool mark impressions in a criminal investigation. The student is
expected to:

C928B98839374113A43DFB30B843C3B3.description:
identify controlled substances using laboratory procedures such as microchemical tests,
microscopy, chromatography, and spectrophotometry.

20BF049D9A4548B1826710E6BB9CE298.description:
classify controlled substances using the schedules under the Controlled Substances Act;
and

DC450363626F42B5850E03603B1A0EC5.description: The student identifies drugs found at a simulated crime scene. The student is expected to:

150BECCBEC3D4EB384E96F2030F09637.description: interpret the components of an electropherogram.

1817E1E0B7D040BC9E474001D678632D.description:
explain the analytical procedure for forensic DNA typing, including electrophoresis,
polymerase chain reaction, and short tandem repeat;

D1AAA24CB035474C86999EE3086EB656.description: describe the steps used in extraction of DNA;

4DE0A5AD69B84770B7E92F7E008473DD.description: describe the structure of a DNA molecule and its function;

5AFCB2A1EE484AADBF4E3FF401BF1B6F.description:
The student analyzes deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) laboratory procedures in forensic science. The
student is expected to:

E7484C0B2EA642F79108887B05A24633.description: research methodologies used to collect and analyze other body fluids.

D5183D64E1A0429F8D48D83B3CFF5CB4.description:
determine genotypes and phenotypes in the human red blood cell system using Punnet
Squares;

A12650A9C78644C7B6401F006E873B18.description: identify the red blood cell antigens and antibodies as they relate to human blood types;

D414FE6F2FD14A6A804B9BE3C40DAC73.description:
explain forensic laboratory procedures to determine if a stain detected in a crime scene is
blood;

0638F433E4674A1B803CB279F0367D7E.description:
The student explores serology laboratory procedures in forensic science. The student is expected
to:

4AD774F3381248A0B99642DD600B811A.description:
explain the precautions necessary in the forensic laboratory for proper preservation of
blood samples

B67224FD52F542C5BF65CA03FE4E4FB3.description: explain the levels of tolerance and impairment due to alcohol consumption;

DFF3532880DC4E7D9376AF53696C44D2.description:
describe the blood alcohol laboratory procedures as they relate to blood alcohol
concentration;

3A8AE48FE20545B0820BB1D96BC03955.description: explain the absorption, distribution, and elimination of alcohol through the human body;

353843DEE4B946BA9781872B301DB0A2.description:
The student explores toxicology laboratory procedures in forensic science. The student is expected
to:

B28E4B604E10428EB6A525AB33F80AFB.description:
explain the method of chemically isolating an invisible blood stain using reagents such as
luminol.

2EED8E2B363844EBB748FC489CDEB41D.description: analyze blood stain patterns based on source, direction, and angle of trajectory;

05D9F4C107A0433494247B10CD2A989D.description: The student analyzes blood spatter at a simulated crime scene. The student is expected to:

E23D1D80B79D46EAB583196EB3D93ACA.description:
compare impression evidence collected at a simulated crime scene with the known
impression.

6326E5F5B8B04BF4A43D3A0440096AE9.description:
explain the Automated Fingerprint Identification System (AFIS) and describe the
characteristics examined in the AFIS;

811F543F019D4E93A75BD9348B7052EF.description:
perform laboratory procedures for lifting latent prints on nonporous objects using
fingerprint powders such as black powder and florescent powders;

AD26BF8CFE4B464D8970DBB6715AA135.description:
perform laboratory procedures for lifting latent prints on porous and nonporous objects
using chemicals such as iodine, ninhydrin, silver nitrate, and cyanoacrylate resin;

2DD53D71569C4DA4B5BAF18A7D2A1CB8.description: distinguish among patent, plastic, and latent impressions;

FD95CBAA7B5E4A508D08F2A6C9653904.description:
identify the minutiae of fingerprints, including bifurcations, ending ridges, dots, short
ridges, and enclosures;

22EB399DA632459D836366CDEE7DEBDE.description:
compare the three major fingerprint patterns of arches, loops, and whorls and their
respective subclasses;

68C09C84AAAE422CA5060F4A664B80D0.description: The student analyzes impression evidence in forensic science. The student is expected to:

60A028D931B24C6598010953B7663086.description:
describe various examinations performed in forensic paint analysis, including
microscopic morphology, binder, and pigment characterization.

1764090CD77E40CCBBD82732C4DD527F.description: differentiate between natural and synthetic fibers;

CB1D96B8F1864322A65F5CBC6503A997.description:
describe and illustrate the different microscopic characteristics used to determine the
racial and somatic origin of a human hair sample;

A0D0BDA1101A4490931E59162B744656.description:
compare and contrast the microscopic characteristics of human hair and animal hair,
including medulla, pigment distribution, and scales;

B43B149B0220418DB1DD5A84D6AD450C.description:
describe the instrumental analysis of trace evidence such as microscopy and
spectrometry;

0130924072AA4D73BE452850B5C01492.description: define refractive index and explain how it is used in forensic glass analysis;

BD1396522FFB42BF9798D8427AEFB1F7.description: determine the direction of a projectile by examining glass fractures;

D973ED2B219A4CACAD277ECE56A94161.description:
compare and contrast the composition of various types of glass such as soda lime,
borosilicate, leaded, and tempered;

39B06E2C568E42EEB1D0FADC39C86642.description:
demonstrate how to process trace evidence such as glass, paint, fibers, hair, soil, grass,
and blood collected in a simulated crime scene;

8A3AA9A093224CFF8B80813C5E387AEA.description:
The student recognizes the methods to process and analyze trace evidence commonly found in a
crime scene. The student is expected to

5FAC327EC6EF41028D27EFEF9E17CBF0.description:
demonstrate proper techniques for collecting, packaging, and preserving physical
evidence found at a crime scene

7BE50E8D7DFF46C8882D2AA225D0FD8A.description: outline the chain of custody procedure for evidence discovered in a crime scene;

78CBD5BE78694FF0A47DEDF407B88945.description: develop a crime scene sketch using coordinates/measurements from fixed points;

44A38E28D4064876B76089ED288FBFC0.description:
describe the elements of a crime scene sketch such as measurements, compass directions,
scale of proportion, legend-key, and title;

3F61B7F4D589499684B8553C4533D553.description:
apply knowledge of the elements of criminal law that guide search and seizure of
persons, property, and evidence;

7D1CCC75209B42A7B31742373DB82011.description:
conduct a systematic search of a simulated crime scene for physical evidence following
crime scene search patterns such as spiral, line, grid, and strip;

C7A4E2D2D4B94441806A6DECF6C8CC36.description: demonstrate the ability to work as a member of a team;

BB28EB6810D045FBB9F67A52E005DFF0.description: compare and contrast the roles of forensic scientists and crime scene investigators;

63EF6654AA474DF784779CEB05FD7B1A.description:
The student recognizes the procedures of evidence collection while maintaining the integrity of a
crime scene. The student is expected to:

12D7C0E007DF47E3876FE1DD2A6C00D8.description:
illustrate the history of forensic science and recognize the major contributors in the
development of forensic science.

55EB3EF7A7014596B26F4637C332D656.description:
explore and demonstrate an understanding of the terminology and the procedures
employed in the criminal justice system;

FA73EDE8252B4FD6B133D5BF822F2DE4.description: summarize the ethical standards required of a forensic science professional;

48900C3B17B64C7FBAB8B87DF3898403.description:
The student explores the history, legal aspects, and career options within forensic science. The
student is expected to:

B9F212066EDA465DB7CA0661A28EF360.description:
research and describe the history of science and contributions of scientists within the
criminal justice system.

80FF1FC674B54EA497EA92F4914D6EED.description:
evaluate models according to their limitations in representing biological objects or
events;

B31285C8A2CF4A28933C06189DA7A734.description:
evaluate the impact of scientific research on criminal investigation, society, and the
environment;

02AAEC2A8D8E433EBF0A19EC6310306C.description: draw inferences based on data related to criminal investigation;

9023589819134B3785F0291446D24C0B.description:
communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as
current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials;

B49E582A0A2B44418AF864616837FB67.description:
The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed
decisions within and outside the classroom. The student is expected to:

7BE79486C6864C16ABC6ACF8F54416AC.description:
communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through methods such as
investigative reports, lab reports, labeled drawings, graphic organizers, journals,
summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports.

C4609D4C69EF4D31BEEB7CC28AF05489.description: analyze, evaluate, make inferences, and predict trends from data;

612B587DCC2F481B95A2370B75CEF9C9.description:
collect and organize qualitative and quantitative data and make measurements with
accuracy and precision using tools such as calculators, spreadsheet software, datacollecting probes, computers, standard laboratory glassware, microscopes, various
prepared slides, stereoscopes, metric rulers, electronic balances, gel electrophoresis
apparatuses, micropipettors, hand lenses, Celsius thermometers, hot plates, lab notebooks
or journals, timing devices, cameras, Petri dishes, lab incubators, dissection equipment,
meter sticks, and models, diagrams, or samples of biological specimens or structures;

765677C15D4247C59A52D65306382EC9.description: distinguish between scientific hypotheses and scientific theories;

9DD3B795C96949949398FCB9DB852069.description:
know scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of
being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories
are well-established and highly reliable explanations, but they may be subject to change
as new areas of science and new technologies are developed;

234E21119671454BAC1C53EF99D62738.description:
know that scientific hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable
of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable
explanatory power that have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are
incorporated into theories;

CB807DD8415449E0A629340C98236862.description:
know the definition of science and understand that it has limitations, as specified in
subsection (b)(4) of this section;

4C41CE4E867A4C48A93247D04F1DEEA6.description:
The student uses scientific methods and equipment during laboratory and field investigations. The
student is expected to:

C5EDC4734F82413BA8CF74C81464B782.description:
demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper
disposal or recycling of materials.

23D7D59FFFBF4E479860FC24BC256A61.description: demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations;

60AD6093C950420D962BD0122DECF05D.description:
The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts laboratory and/or field investigations
using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices. The student is expected to:

EC19A5CFC0404C48B61B78F4AC8D89B1.description:
The student demonstrates professional standards/employability skills as required by business and
industry. The student is expected to achieve business and industry employability skills standards
such as attendance, punctuality, meeting deadlines, working toward personal/team goals every
day, and ethical use of technology.

1DB5CF9944BE4D2B88DA696E9172FBBC.description:
Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those
containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

C5AB20EB576141E5A20B452362AB2DEA.description:
Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and
technical student organizations and other leadership or extracurricular organizations.

69ED031AAC254E3CA4A24AD586131D47.description:
A system is a collection of cycles, structures, and processes that interact. All systems have basic
properties that can be described in terms of space, time, energy, and matter. Change and constancy
occur in systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and modeled. These patterns help to
make predictions that can be scientifically tested. Students should analyze a system in terms of its
components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the external
environment.

E0C209A99D3D407F854FBC17B8EEAA1F.description:
Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the natural world. Students
should be able to distinguish between scientific decision-making methods and ethical and social
decisions that involve the application of scientific information.

38D34C19D501476F93C4D56DE62740F1.description:
Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate investigation of the natural world. Scientific
methods of investigation can be experimental, descriptive, or comparative. The method chosen
should be appropriate to the question being asked.

314779D9A7CE4B4AB41AD4C2FE4658B6.description:
Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct
testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated
through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by
physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are
outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.

9563F92706F34BF2B960F9E4435FC969.description:
Forensic Science is a course that introduces students to the application of science to connect a
violation of law to a specific criminal, criminal act, or behavior and victim. Students will learn
terminology and procedures related to the search and examination of physical evidence in criminal
cases as they are performed in a typical crime laboratory. Using scientific methods, students will
collect and analyze evidence such as fingerprints, bodily fluids, hairs, fibers, paint, glass, and
cartridge cases. Students will also learn the history and the legal aspects as they relate to each
discipline of forensic science.

A324D1392D2A40ACA2EF90DDE386E988.description:
The Law, Public Safety, Corrections, and Security Career Cluster focuses on planning, managing,
and providing legal services, public safety, protective services, and homeland security, including
professional and technical support services.

959828BEA46049C1AD13E101E189903C.description:
Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic
standards and relevant technical knowledge and skills for students to further their education and
succeed in current or emerging professions.

2AFC843F2E624C908C7D81E5B7F38807.description:
General requirements. The course is recommended for students in Grades 11 and 12. Prerequisites: Biology
and Chemistry. Recommended prerequisite or corequisite: any Law, Public Safety, Corrections, and
Security Career Cluster course. Students must meet the 40% laboratory and fieldwork requirement. This
course satisfies a high school science graduation requirement. Students shall be awarded one credit for
successful completion of this course.
